content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												Age of Empires 3 is the third and (seemingly) final game in the Age of Empires series. If you  don't know already, it's a traditional real-time-strategy game set in the colonial and imperial ages of European history, with a little of flair of Asia for kicks. Although Age of Empires games traditionally feature a very strong campaign, the replay factor in AOE is always the multiplayer and skirmish options, and this time players are given a multitude of options to suit their gameplay preferences. As a "turtle" (high defense, weak offense) player, I especially like the "treaty" mode, which turns off combat for a set number of minutes at the beginning of each round and also forces players to build their base within a confined space during that time period. As with previous games in the series, AoE3 features 4 different "age" milestones that allow your civilization to access new technologies and units.The Good:* Trading cards enabled.* Different civilizations, especially those from different continents, have entirely separate styles of play, giving the game different "flavors" of play and replayability.* Rather than just giving each civilization unique units and technologies, AOE3 takes "Uniqueness" a step further by giving every play 21 "bonus cards," which can be used to dramatically alter your play choices. Two players can conceivably play as the same civilization and require completely different strategies and playstyles due to the bonuses given to them by their cards.* Vastly more multiplayer options than the predecessors in the series.* Some Civs, such as the Sioux, are fairly simplistic. This is a positive attribute as it allows differently-skilled players to enjoy the game in their own way.* There is a "home city building" side-game that is a little enjoyable.The Bad:* I feel like a game that supports 1000+ units on the screen and 1920x1080 resolution should let me zoom the map out a bit further. My town center annoyingly takes up way too much of my view!* No Steam achievements.* Antiquated map controls - the only way to scroll the map is by moving your cursor to the edge of the screen. RTS games should support WASD map scrolling and/or click 'n' drag.* The final "age" is rarely ever needed in a match, and costs more than it benefits your team, in my opinion.* Map-editing is nowhere near as easy and intuitive as it was in previous AOE games.* Weak AI. It seems like a 1 vs. 1 AI opponent always focuses strictly on cavalry, which in turn focuses me to only focus on building one type of unit.The Ugly:* Horribly WRONG launcher screen. When starting the game, you are given the choice of loading (a) Age of Empires III: Complete Collection, (b) Age of Empires III: The War Chiefs, and (c) Age of Empires III: Asian Dynasties. However, option "A" is not complete at all: choosing it gives you access to neither of the two expansions. Option B gives you access to the War Chiefs Expansion (but not Asian Dynasties), and Option C gives you access to ALL game content: the base game and both expansions.* Not as fun as AOE2. A sequal should be a step forward, not a step back. The differences are noticeable in all sorts of small areas, which individually would not be a problem, but lend to an overall diminished quality. Some examples are unit formations being nowhere near as "tight," and units having a tendency to WALK into battle if they are grouped with a slower unit.The Verdict:* At the time of this writing, the base price for AO3 is $39.99. That is overpriced, especially since AO2-HD is a more solid and overall better game and comes for the same base price. However, I do think AOE3 is worth checking out if you can get it on sale. I have had a lot of fun with this game, perhaps 100 hours or so, before it ever became available on Steam. But now that AO2-HD has come out, I see little reason to play AO3.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												GameSpot said it best: "Age of Empires III has some very big shoes to fill".It is a very good game, and there are barely any real flaws to speak of, but I still prefer its predecessor, even though almost everything that was good about Age of Empires II is improved here, most noticeably the A.I. and the graphics.Perhaps the historical era covered by the game and its heavy focus on gunpowder in later stages isn't as compelling, and the scenario editor (which played a big part in Age of Empires II's prolonged success) is a little more complicated to use.But the core gameplay, which is easy to understand, but hard to master, remains pretty much the same, with some interesting additions like the "Capital City" and the ability to choose different bonuses as you advance through the ages, a similar system to the one seen in Age of Mythology.If you're a fan of the "Age" series or you just enjoy well-designed, polished real-time strategy games, or are looking to get into the genre, Age of Empires III is definitely worthy of your time and money.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2016
												Super fun game, especially if you play with your friends online. There are many different civilizations to choose from and each one has a unique playstyle which can be strong or weak depending on how you play them and how your enemy plays as well. Very difficult but very fun at the same time. So much strategy and thought goes into every match and you have to make very quick and precise decisions or else you can set yourself behind from the very start and lose extremely easily. Keep in mind that this game is over a decade old now so the graphics are not "cutting edge" but the game still looks good, and graphics don't really matter in this type of game anyways. With how old the game is, the online functionality can be pretty bad at times. I've had many time with my friends where we struggled to all get into the same lobby together as some of us could connect and others literally could not join no matter what. There are rumors of an Age of Empires 4 possibly being made, but I wouldn't count on that too much. Despite the online problems, all the game mechanics work very good and the strategy required to succeed is insane. I recommend this to anyone who likes a thought invoking game.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												This game is worth every single penny. It's a classic RTS game. It's fairly easy to get the jist of. Hell, even I got the hang of it quickly. That really speaks volumes to me. This game is even better when you have someone to play with or against. On occasion, the online service will run into problems and people may not be able to join your game and/or you won't be able to join theirs. I have only recently started to notice this problem (10/31/15) so I am not sure how common it will become. It usually just takes a bit of time to fix itself though.As mentioned before, it's real-time strategy. You get to pick the Civilization that you like the most. These include the Germans, Spanish, British, Asian civs,  Native American civs, and a lot more. Each have their own strategies. In the game, you are pitted against another Civ(s), whether it be an AI or an actual player. Your civilization's economy relies on 3 things: food, wood, and coin. Your villagers, or workers, must work to gather these resources and build your colony. You can use the resources to create buildings, buy improvements, and train an army.Eventually, you'll need an army. There are infantry, calvalry, and artillery units. You can also have naval battles with various ships if there is a body of water on the map. As mentioned before, there are numerous strategies for victory. I'd recommend trying out all the Civilizations and see which one you feel most comfortable with.Overall, this game is godly. It will stand the test of time, and I hope that the online service will remain available for years to come (after all, it still has a sizable community).P.S. There is a fort called Het Huys de Hoop.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
												It should be known by now that I've been a fan of the Age games from way back. There's just something about the historical nature of the games that appeals to me. To be fair, I think elves and space marines are neat too, but I think it's more exciting to explore the what ifs of real, historical situations. Though not quite as faithful to "reality" as some strategy games, the first two Age games offered us exciting sojourns into the worlds of "capital A" Ancient and Medieval strategy. The third title, Age of Mythology, proved that the mechanics were just as solid even if the historical inspiration was a little loose.Now Ensemble is back on the history train with the third official Age of Empires game. Age of Empires III moves the action to the New World, letting players lead a variety of European nations from the Age of Discovery through the Industrial Age. Eight playable nations battle across a wide variety of geographies -- from the swamps of Florida to the snowy passes of the Rocky Mountains. Players can recruit different Native American tribes and seize control of various trade routes. Material and technological support will be offered by the player's home city back in Europe.The 24-mission campaign is very well designed. Divided into three large acts, it tells the story of three generations of the Black family. First Morgan Black, a Knight of St. John races to the New World to stop the Spanish from seizing a powerful natural wonder. Next, Morgan's grandson John and his Native American allies find themselves in the Seven Year's War. The final act shows John's granddaughter Amelia as the head of a railroad company making their way west.I won't spoil the particulars of the story here but a common quest and a common enemy unite all three acts. The connections aren't always clear at first, but the associations start to build as the game goes on. Putting the pieces together isn't terribly hard but it gives a nice sense of purpose to the whole game and keeps you invested in the action.While we're talking about the game's story, it's refreshing to see a game that covers this era of warfare without referencing either Napoleon or the American Revolution. While both are fertile ground for strategy game developers, it's nice to get something a little different this time around. Meeting Washington and Bolivar and taking part in the Seven Year's War adds a little authenticity as well as variety. On the other hand, some of the choices -- like finding Russians in Colorado -- may leave gamers scratching their heads in wonder.The range of missions is pretty broad. There are plenty of defense missions where you have to protect a given structure or a whole town from enemy assault. In other cases you'll have to destroy or capture key structures. Along the way there are plenty of other objectives: rescuing captured settlers, seizing trading posts, liberating Native American settlements and a whole host of other tasks. Better still, many missions combine a variety of these objectives at once. While most of the missions let you build a base and start collecting resources, there are some missions where you have to make do with a set number of troops.Outside of the single player campaign, Age of Empires III benefits from a very soild multiplayer interface. A few simple clicks take you to ESO2, Ensemble's online matchmaking service. Finding and joining games is remarkably easy and there are a wide variety of options to choose from. Different starting eras and resource levels will let players jump into as advanced a game as they want. The AI offers up a few taunts from time to time to (sort of) replicate the personality of a human player. It's a nice trick honestly.In general the AI is very strong. You can find some exploits here and there but, for the most part, the AI knows how to make a good army and how to lead it. While the computer opponents in some RTS games send out trickles of units from time to time in order to keep things interesting, the AI in Age of Empires III tends to rely more on groups of units and will hardly ever use them in pointless, suicide attacks. In my games the AI has had a good handle on when to press an attack and when to retreat. The only real weak point in the AI is its tendency to leave some of its settlers too isolated. (Since there are no resource dropsites anymore, it's also hard for human players to keep tabs on where all their settlers are.)The range of technologies and units is relatively broad here. In the early ages, players will have to make do with troops that are very similar to the medieval set from Age of Empires II. Crossbows eventually give way to muskets as the ages pass by. Soon players will be fielding long lines of musketeers and using mortars to bombard enemy towers. While it may seem that some of the unit types are redundant, you'll find that each type has a specific role to play on the battlefield. Like the other Age games you'll have a variety of ranged and melee-focused cavalry and infantry as well as a nice range of artillery units. Identifying the counter units and building a balanced force is just as important as knowing where and when to strike the enemy.Like the rest of the games in the Age series, the naval element is merely there to support the land battles. The handful of ships and maritime technologies don't offer many options. You will find that the naval side of the game is fairly compelling early on while you're dealing with pirates and chasing your enemies across the Atlantic. Once you start fighting in the interior of the American continent, you won't really miss the naval aspect of the game as much.Pathfinding seems to be a bit of a problem here and there. Huge formations can easily find their way through the most densely packed settlements but my one hero unit can't seem to find his way out of the middle of a line of infantry. There are cases where the pathfinding is a little too good. Units are able to predict the best routes through a maze even when large parts of that maze haven't been uncovered yet. This is most telling during missions where you're leading a small force through a series of winding canyons. As long as you click on their eventual destination, they'll make their way through the labyrinth with nary a wrong turn.While we're on the subject, it seems odd that you can't select a single unit out of a group by clicking on their portrait at the bottom of the screen. Trying to grab a specific hero unit out of a large formation should be easier than this. Luckily, there's an option in the game to disregard any non-combat units when you click and drag to select a group. This helps to keep your settlers from marching out with your soldiers.Age of Empires III also introduces some new elements -- home cities, native tribes, trade routes and such. Taken individually none of these are profound innovations but their cumulative effect makes the game feel fresh and strengthens the appeal of the core design. So in total of this review, I recommend this game to anyone who loves RTS Games.

												It should be known by now that I've been a fan of the Age games from way back. There's just something about the historical nature of the games that appeals to me. To be fair, I think elves and space marines are neat too, but I think it's more exciting to explore the what ifs of real, historical situations. Though not quite as faithful to "reality" as some strategy games, the first two Age games offered us exciting sojourns into the worlds of "capital A" Ancient and Medieval strategy. The third title, Age of Mythology, proved that the mechanics were just as solid even if the historical inspiration was a little loose.Now Ensemble is back on the history train with the third official Age of Empires game. Age of Empires III moves the action to the New World, letting players lead a variety of European nations from the Age of Discovery through the Industrial Age. Eight playable nations battle across a wide variety of geographies -- from the swamps of Florida to the snowy passes of the Rocky Mountains. Players can recruit different Native American tribes and seize control of various trade routes. number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 26, 2016
												Following on from the monumental success that was Age of Empires II, this third installment brings the franchise into the light with jaw-droppingly amazing graphics and a style of gameplay that is a dream to play. The attention to detail is astounding, from everything to cracks in a townhouse just about ready to crumble, to the wide range of sound effects ranging from hilarously stereotypical comments from Isabella of Spain to Frederick the Great of Germany, to the sounds of canons such as the Falconets. Even the different environments manage to evoke a sense of belonging, as if one is truly standing in the snow in Siberia, or sweating bullets in Caribbean - not an easy feat for a strategy game to achieve. The fact that no major installment have been released since (Age of Empires IV anyone?) is simply a testament to the replay value and endurance of one of the all-time greatest strategy games released.VERDICT: 10/10

												I would definitely recommend this game !! I had this game on disc copy many years ago , and i have played endless hours all have been fun. content:
Posted: November 20, 2015
												I played this game when it came out 10 years ago. The conventional thinking is that Age of Empires II is the "best," but the truth is that Age of Empires III is actually the best.I'll make it simple. Age of Empires III is better because it's newer and it's more of a game and less of a time killer. There is actually a single-player with a real story to the campaign. There are a ton of different units in the game and I haven't even gotten to the DLC yet. This version is more fast-paced and is equally as fun on land as it is on water.There is one issue that isn't major, but it kind of is for me. That is the game hasn't been updated in a while and doesn't allow for steam overlay (shift+tab) and does not contain any achievements. I'm not sure if the game supports 4K either.I am using WIndows 10 with a GTX 970 and i5-4466. There are absolutely no technical hiccups and the game runs very smooth.Overall, great game that surpasses Age of Empires II in every way while looking GREAT for its age. Also, no major bugs or compatibility issues with Windows 10. Needs update to add new steam features like the Shift+Tab overlay and achievements.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2016
												Summary: Age of Empires III offers gamers the next level of realism, with advanced battle physics and unparalleled visual detail. The new game picks up where Age of "Empires II: Age of Kings" left off, placing gamers in the position of a European power determined to explore, colonize and conquer the New World. This time period features stunning scenes, from towering European cathedrals to courageous tribes of Native Americans, and spectacular combat with Industrial Age units like rifled infantry, cavalry and tall ships bristling with cannons. Age of Empires III excites strategy gamers with new game-play elements, including the concept of a "Home City," new civilizations, units, technologies and an immersive new single-player campaign that will span three generations. Recommendation: I crucially recommend this game to all Strategic game lovers :)

If you're interested in rts, history, or strategy even a little bit, you won't want to pass this game up.

												Better than AOE 2 ofcourse :)Play the game for a lil bit, Like it.... This game is a small scale war, unlike C&C Series or Total War Series.Simple RTS game with max population cap to 200. Mid-Age wars with horse, sword, lance, bow, and cannon artillery.Why it's better than AOE 2 :+ Significant graphic improvement+ Significant Improvement in gameplay+ Neutral campaign on maps (defeat the treasure guardians to get bonus for early  level)+ Trading Post available on maps (Neutral area which can be post by ur building for extra content) + U can train 5 units at once per queue, except worker+ Card System. This is used for shipment (shipment is somekind of a free bonus given to u for leveling up in the game)+ Unlockable & Costumizable Shipment (Various bonus that can be used in game)+ Indian Tribes have Warpit, and the other side Western country have Factory The bad thing in AOE 3 : - Towers has a limited build to 7.- Town Center can't be build by workers, instead by Hero / Explorer / WarChief & sent by shipment.- Town Center has build limit- Military units no longer can be garrison into castle or towers- Castle is an exclusive building, can't be build by workers instead by shipment.Well I don't like to play the Asian Dynasties anyway it's imba, just stick with The Warchief expansion.Having fun with this installment,  not the best RTS game on the market, but  'S awright to givin' 2 thumbs up for tis game.About the online multiplayer ? i dunno, never try it, cause  i play it just for single player fun mode only :DScore : 80/100

content:
Posted: January 11
												AoE 3 is the third installment in the series, offers an intriguing main single player story as various characters search for the fountain of youth. The single player skirmishes, custom made games, and multiplayer is the bread and butter of the game. In single player skirmishes, enemies are further apart, giving your base time to upgrade and build your army to your specifications before attacking enemy camps. You receive experience points when in battle, building, working, etc. Combat is much better than in AoE2, but unless you are playing on harder difficulties, the AI isn't as good as in AoE2.  This time around you  get wars dogs as well as cannons, and other weapons. You can build decks of cards for the shipments to your colony, forge alliances with natives or other allies to take over the new world.  There are a few things in the game that is annoying. 1. You can't put your soldiers in patrolling mode, you have to manually put them where you want them to be. 2. The npcs are dumber than a bag of rocks. Workers will just stand there while being attack instead of fighting back, soldiers will ignore enemies attack them while they are attacking buildings. 3.They have taken out most of the different matches from AoE2 like King of the Hill, Capture the Relic, Wonder Race, Deathmatch (where you start with supplies), and other matches that made AoE2 great making this game a dumb down version of AoE2. It is still a very good game in the series it just lacks depth. The music is okay and the graphics are beautiful I just wish it had more to offer. 8/10. A good strategy game to own.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
												Age of Empires series was supposed to be the best series around - as I've read through many and many reviews. Many people recommended this game and when I saw it on sale I gave it a shot. Basically, this game is like European Wars : Cossacks. Old style RTS. The only downside to this Age of Empires versus the second is the way you can choose formations in the second. It felt overall the second had more to control whereas the third sort of simplified things and tried to make the game easier and smoother. AoE 3 is your typical RPG, offering peasants (or settlers), militias, markets, church's, walls and gates to protect your city. I really can't see all the hype about this game to be truthful as everyone says. Yes the campaign stories are good, but I find that this game doesn't really set itself apart from other RTS's. If I had a choice between playing European Wars : Cossacks or this - I would most likely choose EW : Cossacks. Not to say that this game is bad, but the options that are given in EW far outweigh those of AoE for me. I would give it an 8 if it had something to differentiate itself from other RTS of it's class, but RATING : 7.6/10Gameplay B Story / Campaign B- Visuals / User Interface B- Sounds / Music C+ Replay-ability B- Overall  B-

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
Addressing Concers for the GameThis reaches back to memories. I remember playing this game back when I was a kid. It was either my first or second RTS game that I still play even today. There are balancing problems, but I'm not the guy who favors the idea of balancing. However, it is worth noting that there are problems with certain civilations within the game as I spend the majority of my time in the multiplayer.Multiplayer Civilation Problems/Underdogs/My Opinion and ConcernsSome civilations, even through balancing with the popuation and resources, are just underdogs on their economy or just plain tough suckers who are hard to kill. An example of this are the Azetcs and the French. The Azetcs have food eco. power, but they lack in earning gold to pay for required units to counter such others. The French have an elite calvary that my cost alot in food, gold, and population. However, even that balancing doesn't stop them from being massively produced quickly and used effienctly. It becomes a redundant tactic to use in multiplayer games. Other civilations also have such advantages like the Russians using advance formations with seige calvary surrounding a horse archer to form a compact square formation in treaty games. This would generally cause massive economic damages and strategic disappointment for the opposing team. There are more in the game, but these are just a few examples.Unit Combat/Understanding of the UnitsThe game has unit balancing that kills the reality of what would really happen at the time, but I don't blame them for that balancing. An example is that a lightly armored unit can be have resistance to guns and arrows, and the same can be side to heavly armored Chinese units. I'm not saying that all firearms and archaic bows can break through dense armor, but I believe that the game should be updated to the point where things can make some sense and use. This is because that every unit within the game have only one resistance to a certain type of attack. There is the seige, the ranged, and the melee attack. Each has a different use and affect on certain units. There are even other units that can absorb lots of balls from muskeets and still not die. Even when they are lightly armored. I do want to note and point out my understanding that the game is an old RTS from 2005 with a golden RTS combat system, but looking at this just breaks my reality I put in the game.EconomyEach and every map in the game that are offical are designed differently with certain arount of food (animals/berries/treasures), gold (mines/treasures), and wood (trees). In addition, there are certain sites that can improve the players economy, such as trading posts. Do you that everything that is "natural" in the map is a consumable.  So, this makes them a nonreliable source of income. To further worsen this, they are all spread out through out the map. This stress the player to try to control the map and protect their gathers from hurrassments, which is what I like. What I don't like is that when the map runs out of trees, I have to rely on trading at the market. The market is a building that is used to upgrade your gathers to increase gathering rate. In the game, upgrades will generally consume two of the resources (food,wood, or gold) to perform upgrade for combat unit, gathering, minor improvements, and etc. Now, the problem with every map in the game is when the trees are all gone. Wood is esstential for constructing buildings and certain units. When wood is gone, this causes the player to rely on the markets or vulgar production from factions, trading post, and wood producing units. They don't produce a decent needed amount that is need for the battle. This makes pikemen and longbows useless; one of the few units that can counter French calvary are upgraded pikemen. Some civilations don't need to worry about wood income like Japan. Their shrines can generate a lot when upgraded and max. However, for them to generate more they need animals. In standard games, Japan is a faction that you might not want in your team due the fact that some players will generally take animals you use as food for their purposes. When that happens, you can't kill the animal for food. They are protected by the shrine from being killable or taken. This leads to another topic about popuation that I'll explain about later; Japan has a small limit of the amount of villagers that can produce. Back to topic, this causes Japan to become dependent on animals and other players to produce domesticated animals for them. Even more...Home cities are cities that provide aid to the player in the game. They do so by shipping passive upgrades that are unique to certain civilations, standard upgrades, consumbles, units, buildings, or ships for the cost of points(levels). Points are earned by reaching a ceratin xp (level (> or = to) xp). Xp is earned naturally, produced, or in bountry of a unit's death. Not all civilations can have passive upgrades to improve their economy to a decent or dramatic advantage. Take a look at the Aztecs. They can bloom their food production so well, but lacking in gold production to train certain units. To make this even worse for them, they can't have access to resource production type buildings or enchance to gathering like the Indians. Same can be said about all Native American civilations, and their firepits can screw up their uses of villagers in desprite times.PopulationMost Civilations have a popuation limit. This is a balance to pervent overwhelming quanity of units that we are all not interesting in coming at use. However, the there are limits in the amount of units each civilations have train. Most civilations can train upto 99 villagers/settlers/gathers (the three are interchangable). However, those who gets a benefits on their economy has a reduction to the amount of villagers they can have. This is a balance to pervent massive generation of income for a civilation. Do know that there are ways to lose a game. One of them is lose all your gathers, your town center, and your hero. So, those with lower villager counts are in a risk if they aren't protected. What I like:Decent Amount of CivilationsDecent Amount of UnitsAdvance Formations OptionsGood Options/Setting for a 2005 GameA Stable Way of IncomeMap Control is KeyUnit Combat is OkayVillager Gathering is OkayCivilations are uniqueWhat I want... Updates maybe and less redundant actions in the game? If you guys have any concerns about stuff you want me to address I'll add them below here. Questions about game mechanics will be answered in the comments. Anything that is etc. will also be answered in the comments. If there are grammar mistakes or something you want me to take another look back in the review please also note them in the comments ,too. content:
Posted: May 27, 2012
												Age of Empires III, is by far my most favorite RTS game of all time. It is a well balanced masterpiece with plenty to do that will keep you busy for hours. Well balanced as in, it has that mixture to where it isn't too militaristic. You spend a lot of time improving your economy. Between building your Empire, leveling and customizing your home city, and developing new technologies, you'll be hard crossed to go to bed at a decent time. It has multiplayer, thirty or so maps, a scenario editior, and twelve unique nations ranging from the powerful British Empire to the traditional Japanese. This game is beautiful, even on my potato battery laptop. I've been in love with this game since 2005. I lost my retail copy so i was thrilled when it was added to the Steam Store. MANY more people should know about this game. It has tons of depth, and is one of the few games from Microsoft i love. Do yourself a favor, and buy this game! It is most certainly worth the hefty price tag!

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												*Note: I have very little time played on my Steam version of this game, but have played around 80 - 100 hours on the disc version.*Age of Empires III incorporates an awesome New England settings rendered in amazing graphics. The combat is more intense, more diverse, and much more realistic than that of the original two Age of Empires games, which were already great. The interface has been updated and greatly improved (only three resources allow for a smoother process of building and running your civilation). The game has many great new features, including:-use of a "home city", a city you customize and level up through battle, that serves as your main menu and gives rewards-ability to train troops in groups of five, instead of individually-random capturable treasures scattered around the map that give unique bonuses-more realistic battle (soldiers burn buildings instead of hit them, cannonballs knock down trees, ships sink, etc)-awesome revamped naval combat. Limited fleet size allow more tactical fighting strategies-unit special abilities. these vary greatly, providing a single powerful shot, treasure gaurdian taming, stealth, etc.-ability to build trade posts to ally with native americans, providing unique/powerful upgrades and native units-use of limited and highly-profitable trade posts along a railroad, which are visciously fought over-unique use of ability cards, picked outside of battle, and used during game for special advantages-highly diverse wild animals to fight, hunt, and tame. Tamable ones includes wolves, coyotes, bears, cougars, and more.-interesting and useful incorporation of time-period features, including minute-men, trains, native allies, and more.-addition of artillery units (various cannons) that add a unique element to combat-(with Asian Dynasties expansion) ability to play as one of three native American tribes (Sioux, Aztec, and one other)Things I do not like about this game:-population size still limited to 200 units-artillery is a bit overpowered (specifically anti-infantry artillery, though it is more realistic that way)In short, if you are a fan of the original two AoE games, love historical time period-set war games, like strategy combat, or just want to have some great fun on an amazingly underrated and easy-to-learn game, buy Age of Empires III now. And while you're at it, the expansions are great and well worth the money.9.5/10 - Highly, highly recommended.

content:
Posted: February 8
												After the critically-acclaimed Age of Empires 2 was released and the expansion of Conquerors was extremely well received, Age of Empires III was bound to happen. And it did in 2009. Moving away from the Conquistador era, AoE III takes places around the 1700's when Settlers began to populate the American continent. For starters, the graphics changed from the sprites used in AoE II to a tridimensionally rendered objects in AoE III and that made it extremely unpopular for some, as the hardware necessities the software needed were not average. But all in all, the graphical performance of AoE III was extremely well done and on par with other RTS games of the era. Unfortunately, the RTS gaming era was about to end, with AoE III marking a significant decrease in interest the gamers had in this type of games. What was it? One wonders. The gameplay was extremely similar, and yet the charm AoE II had was somehow missing. The AI was not extremely hard and the games had all kinds of countries to be chosen from. The expansions made AoE III a bit better, with the return of ancient civilizations being an option just like in the Conquerors expansion. Unfortunately this made a small impact to the decreasing interest in this RTS. However, it still is a fun game to play. In 2017 it is a game that doesn't require extreme processing power and it is graphically pretty. The investment is well done nowadays. If you feel a little nostalgic and want to play one of the last RTS games of the era,Buy it, play it and don't regret it.8.5/10

content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												The game that reassigned the life goals of thousands of angry real-time strategy nerds who relentlessly blasted death metal out of their sterephones while molesting the taunt buttons when it first came back - is still alive and well. That is, perhaps not so much as when it first premiered, but AoE 3 still attracts a considerable amount of gamers which is impressive given how the strategy gaming industry was completely dwarfed with upsurge of other games is latter years. There's not much of a gripe you can hold against this now-classic: the texture and gameplay is focused and realistic, in startling contrast to the puerile graphics of the prequel (although I won't hold back that Age 2 also rocked) as well as the addition of the home city, which granted a completely new dynamic to the game. As is the problem with most strategy games, the inherently incoherent AI (some kind of stratagem devised by evil game planners to render games inconsistent and all puddy) is a bit problematic, but it's still something that can be coped with. The Online could definitely use some revitalizations, though. Yeah, everyone knows Ensemble Studios called it quits years ago, but still... can't someone do something to add some color to the online community and gameplay? The lack of updates is unnerving.However, AoE retains its place as one of the best RTS games, ever. Even the two expansion packs kicked♥♥♥♥♥ Asian Dynasties in particular added an exotic and 'colonial' palette to the game that made it even more memorable for me. The addition of three new factions (China, India, Japan) certainly made the game the well-nigh perfect, multinational, multi-tactical strategy delight. So without further ado, here's what you would expect from AoE 3:1)Strategy rampage.2)Fast-as♥♥♥♥♥♥cavalry running down your hapless peasants.3)Slow-as-dirt peasants 'collecting' resources.4)No corpses.5)Finding a mother♥♥♥♥ing enemy base near your town center just because you didn't have a proper sight.6)Wreckage.7)Learning the basic words for most languages.8)General ♥♥♥♥ed-upedness on the battlefield when your batallion of musketeers get creamed by a few cannons.9)Magical unicorn-horses attached to artillery that appear whenever the artillery piece has to be carried and disappear when you start shootin'.10)Free geography, history and zoology lessons.11)Free philosophy lessons from Monks or other atavistic religious dudes whom you'll name after your ex-girlfriend's pet iguana - who can literally outwit their opponents by a having a thick-as-♥♥♥♥ smoke (did they even have that stuff in China back then?) .12)Flying numbers.13)Paying attention to the meticulous numerical details of every unit until you realize that your horde of 100 pikemen can be ♥♥♥♥ed by a pack of rockets.14)Epic flanking action.15)Facing stubborn ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who wouldn't give in even after you've destroyed their town centers.16)Taunts! (number 15 in particular)17)Witnessing the beauty of a New England forest until ramming it down with a barrage of mortars.18)Imperialism. Exploitation.19)Where every Wall Street magnate begins: the 100 wood market.20)Stupid ♥♥♥♥ing peasants getting stuck in between the buildings that they built.21)Tresures guarded by wolves, dogs, jaguars and other animals who pack a serious punch.22) Treasures that can be literally collected by empty ships (because ♥♥♥♥ you that's why) .23)Literally immortal colony explorers who yell like 9-year-old ♥♥♥♥♥es when they 'die' and start clutching their stomachs in agony as if they're on their period.24)Stupid ♥♥♥♥ing population limits.25)Villagers that sigh for unexplained reasons whenever they spawn.26)Realizing that the narrator from the tutorial is the same guy as Arkantos fron Age of Mythology!And so forth. It's a fun ride. You'll learn along the way.So yeah, go buy the game. It's not like you've anything better to do.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												Whether you are a fast paced strategist or a laid back gamer, Age of Empires might be the game for you. Personally, I can't keep up with the many skilled players in the online PvP part of the game, however, I enjoy the more personal single player skirmishes that AoE has to offer. That is not say that the community is terrible, because it is just exactly the opposite. When I first was trying to learn the hotkeys and tips and tricks of the experts, there were many players willing to take their time and guide me when I needed guidance. As you may have seen from the trailers and videos of this game, there is much fun to be had. The beauty of being able to conquer another empire is a victory in and of itself. It is a great game to come home to and just unwind from the stresses of the day. The campaign mode can be quite easy, so I recommend trying to challenge yourself and set the difficulty a bit higher than you normally would. The AI in the game can be slow and unchallenging should you choose the normal or easy settings. Also, the story is very cinematic so try to watch the video bits if that's your thing.Overall, I highly recommend this game. It is great for all ages of players.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												Age of Empires 3 is my favorite game. Yes, that places it infront of other video game giants, including Arma, Warband, Civilization, and perhaps more appropriately, Age of Empires 2.It's not the graphics... it's definately not the graphics. They're not bad per se, in fact they are sometimes beautiful, but compared to the standard rts of today, they probably rank 4 or 5 out of 10.AoE 3 is my favorite game because it's *fun*. Over the last decade or so, I've loved and then grown tired of dozens of games, Fallout 4 being the most recent victim. Age 3, however, is always fun. AI provides a challenge, the community is still amazingly friendly and going strong, there are tournaments where you can win cash prizes, plenty of mods, and a quite large amount of diverse factions. When you drop yourself into a game, both single and multiplayer, it's an engaging experience every time. Honestly, I can't even find the words to explain why it's always so fun, it just is. Perhaps it's the historical care given to each unit, or maybe the ridiculous cheats and snarky comments of the AI, I don't know. If I said every game was completely unique, I'd be lying; but that's not a problem, because Age 3 does what works.I usually don't like writing reviews, especially ones over 9 words, but this game deserves at least a little bit of support from me. It's the least I can do for the most captivating game on the steam market.

												Fun variation on the age of empires formula, many features are "streamlined" and aoe-lovers might turn their nose on that.For example the workers don't have to make the trip back with the resources, this completely removes the skill involved (where once you had to properly place a gathering building, abuse sweetspots and manage workers, here you just tell the workers to gather X resource until it runs out) but allows for the game to run a lot faster.Many changes in aoe3 are like that, a gameplay feature is changed or removed completely so that the matches last less.But it's not just a "simpler age of empires set in colonial times", it adds 2 features that distinguish it from the ancestor and cousins completely: hereos and shipments.Age of empires doesn't have "important" units, everything is sacrificable as long as you spent less compared to the enemy's losses worth. Because of this the idea of a powerful RPG-like "hero" unit is not only heretical it's illogical and goes against the concept itself, does it work in aoe3?It doesn't and it does.It's not really an actual hero, it's an explorer unit that you can use for scouting or for clearing "creep camps" that give you a bit (or a lot, if the camp is big) of resources that you can use to strengthen your army, or build buildings. Other than clearing "monsters" the hero can build trading posts, these can be used to connect to neutral camps that give you a (weak) unit to train and (sometimes good) improvements for your economy, or travel routes which give you experience and this connects us to the next part the "trading cards" system:The experience points you gain through certain buildings don't go to your hero or any unit in your army, but instead allow you to receive "shipments" from the mainland. Meaning you can get moscow/amsterdam/istanbul (or whatever your home city is) to send you a shipment of resources, extra villagers, buildings, improvements, entire armies to help you fight.Aoe2 (and aoe) while fun in its own way, suffered from its length, only at 10 minutes you get to age up, aoe3 uses the above to "fix" that, with enough skill, by 10 minutes you might hit the last age.Not everybody can get there, but it's possible.Other than the several races, the shipment system can be edited allowing for a deeply personalized "deck" and gameplay style, takes a while to get used to, but the standard deck isn't painful to play with either.The servers work, and people still play, there's a consistent community that still gets to hone their skills.do you recommend this game?Not for 30 dollars, but the game goes on sale pretty regularely, get it then, it's well worth it if you want a faster  (but by no means simpler) age of empires title.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2014
												I am a big fan of the AOE series, and history. This game is brilliant, although the AI may be silly at times *cough, Napolean* it still has unique gameplay and good graphics, as well a Pretty decent uprgade system. I loved the fact that different units would take up a certain amount of population, e.g. A dragoon would take up 2 population where as apose to a musketeer taking up 1. There is a huge variety of map choices and with the Asian dynasties pack and The war cheifs DLC, the selection choices are endless, they vary from the Amazon River, The Andes, Anywhere in the America's and even the Asian Maps. What I love most though is the story based campaigns, I have finished the Asian one's which I find very addicting, but the way the whole plot goes together makes it so intresting, the characters always serve a unique purpose on the battlefeild, + they are well designed.My favourte part in my Japanese campaign, was when I sent a group of Ninjas into the enemy base using stealth mode, to assassinate the leading daimyo, Immedialty after his death, a rebellion started and I gained control of most of the map. :P +1 BodygaurdsBoromir approves 9.5/10

content:
Posted: April 26, 2016
												Classic Real-Time Strategy set in during the colonisation of the Americas. Play as several European empires, the Dutch, German, French, British, Spanish etc. in multiplayer battles consisting of constructing a base, forming an economy, training an army and pillaging your enemies. Game modes range from FFA, TDM, King of the Hill, Treaty, Supremacy or Deathmatch and custom scenarios. Single-player campaign serves as great starting point for novices of the series to learn how to play before making the leap into multiplayer. Great for LAN parties.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
Pointless nostalgic introBack in 2005, when AoE III was released, I'd already been playing the 2nd for several years. Being an amateur and enthusiast of medieval warfare, the period of time didn't seem too appealing to me. Moreover, I was so used to the iconic 2D graphics of the first 2 AoE titles, that I couldn't join yet the revolution Age of Mythology had started some time earlier.Then, I found a torrent for the vanilla plus TWC somewhere in 2009 or '10 and it didn't took a while before I developed a passion for the game. But enough of my personal history and feelings with the game's series.Actual review and ratingI rate the whole expanded game 8/10*. If I were you I would wonder what's wrong with the game so that you didn't rate it 10/10? The main reason I didn't entirely like AoE III was:-Lack of deep european theatreWhich subsequently implies the game lacks the following content (more or less):-European maps and respective natives (local inhabitants that commonly formed regional cultures)-European conflicts within Europe (like the Napoleonic Wars)-European major factions/civilisations like the Austrians, the Swede, the Poles, the HRE, and so on-European "minor" factions between which most of the mentioned-above conflicts occured (e.g. the thirty years' war?)-I could go on for ages*I rate the vanilla 7/10, and Asian Dynasties 9/10. I liked the accuracy and dedication towards the Asian cultures and peoples, perhaps the crappiest part was that they didn't bother changing the town noise and sounds at all. I cannot say anything about the Warchiefs because I played the native factions very little and am myself not-so experienced with (post-colonisation) north and mesoamerican civilisations.Many by now are probably already thinking that the review is pointless because "muh europe", but hey, we successfully founded the first advanced civilisations, kingdoms and later empires - ultimately colonising the world. So, whether you like that or not it's history, and we're a large part of it.Anyway, if you want to know how good the game is, just read older and more rated reviews. I can simply tell you that if you're looking after a traditional RTS set right after the middle ages until the beginning of the 19th century, you won't be disappointed at all. In case you agree with me on the lack of the European content, I highly recommend you install the Napoleonic Era mod[www.ne.elpea.net]. It adds some 5/6 factions and a bunch of units, maps, etc. It also has a small online community.

content:
Posted: March 27, 2016
												This is the best Age of Empires game and one of the best strategy games of all time. Ships are big and beefy, cannons are cannons that do huge damage and splash and each civilization is unique. In AoE 2, you have crossbowmen shooting arrows at stone walls, battering rams hitting farm fields and making them burn, and swordsmen using their swords to beat down structures. In AoE 3, units have their own siege attacks and animations which fix that problem. Every civ's Church or religious building is a different model. Every civ has their own unique units and tech trees.The Explorer is your colony's leader and sort of a hero-like unit from Warcraft 3. You get to explore the map, fight neutrals and claim treasures during the start of the game, which makes games less repetitve and more fun in the beginning.The Home City part of the game is awesome. You can send shipments or technologies from your mother country to your colony. Every civ has a ton of different strategies.Each map is different enough. Most maps have Native people and settlements that you can trade with or ally. Your mother country will give you additional support on some maps, like early shipments or free economic starting buildings. There are also trade routes that you can establish.The game has good balance, almost rock-paper-scissors, with various types of infantry, cavalry and artillery. Also, farms and plantations do not need to be 'queued' like in AoE 2, fixing any annoyance from that game.In conclusion, AoE 3 is the most improved and well made Age of Empires yet. Every civilization is unique and all the annoying or bad features from the previous Age of Empires series games have been fixed. Each time you play will be different and every civ has different strategies. The maps are all different. My favorite part of the game is the sound of distant artillery, which echoes far! This is a great game and I am glad it is on steam, now it will continue to be supported!

content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												One of my favourite childhood games. Age Of Empires III is an fantastic game even for one of the older games, it's definetely one of the best older games you'll find here on Steam!Select between many countries and defend your home city/colony in skirmish mode, play online multiplayer with up to 8 players! Create a home city and level up to customize it! Make cities, forts, and train soldiers and war ships to defend your base with over 35 new maps to try out and explore! Create your own heroic explorer for your country and use him/her in skirmish mode!Play the exciting 3 original campaigns stories with 2 new campaign stories to enjoy with the DLCS installed!There is loads to do in this game and it just never get's old, always loved playing this game. One of my all time favourite!In-game music is great and the graphics are pretty good and you can create your own levels/maps with the scenario editor! Have fun using brand new hilarious cheat console commands lol :-DClassic World war game, much fun and is absolutely fantastic! Best age of empires game by a long shot!This is a must have game for your steam library!This is a really great game this but I would most like to see an James Cameron Avatar, the Hobbit, and an How to train your dragon age of empires game as well, be even cooler :-D10/10Game Rating: PG (Mild Violence)Catagory: Adventure, Strategy

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												A very entertaining and balanced RTS. It is probably my favourite RTS out there. I find that the home cities/ shipments mechanic really adds a cool dynamic that is completely unique to AoEIII. Each European faction has similar core units (hussars, musketmen, ect) but each has a few unique units and upgrade paths, similar to AoEII. However each of the expansion factions look and play completely unique from the rest of the factions. 9/10 hard AI can be ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t sometimes

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 6, 2014
												One of the best new features in AoEIII is unfortunately also the one that keeps me from enjoying it as much as I have enjoyed other games in the series. The introduction of the Home City was a pretty radical departure for the series, introducing persistent leveling to your favorite civilizations, with immediate and powerful gameplay modifications tailored by you to enhance and compliment your playstyle. On the one hand, this feature works great and is very enjoyable, as you pick and choose 'cards' before going into each match, which might upgrade your units, or your production, or they might give you free units, or unlock abilities. On the other hand, you'll quickly realize that each civilization has its own Home City and you have to play each and every one of them for dozens of matches if you want to competitively play all of them. If you have one or two favorite civs that you'll be playing all the time then that's no problem; you can focus on your favorites and be happy as a clam. If you enjoy playing them all though, and are a fan of the Random Civ option from previous games, then the removal of that feature and the introduction of persistence may irritate you.Other than that, all I'd have to say is that this is a great RTS, with good campaigns, good civilization variety, artwork, music, sound design, gameplay, and scenario editor. Highly recommended.

content:
Posted: March 25, 2016
												It's a fantastic experience  how you never stop learning new things about this mysterious explorer lost in the new world..The way you feel when you start the game for the first time, and you have to build those silly towncenters and you have no clue of what they do.How scared you are at first raid, when the enemy trashtalks to you for the first time.When you figure out which keys do what, and why.How you get to feel when you figure out how to play.When you figure out what goes where and why, and why it shouldn't go somewhere else.When you figure out how to play your favorite civilization, you feel surreal...The sadness that fills you, as your first  settler (that you became so attached to) slowly dies , and you cannot do anything becouse the enemy is in the Imperial Age already..When you have to make a new one..When you figure out that you are lost, you hit the resign button..When you achieve defeat... you feel like you are worthless..But then.. you realize you have to do it again..And the old feelings become new.

content:
Posted: May 31, 2014
												An awesome game.Pros:- It has a shallow learning curve making it very easy for anyone to play.- A large selection of units allows you to build a very customisable & efficient army.- Stunning visuals even for a game that came out years ago.- Wide variety of units, unit types and upgrades - AOE3 allows users to participate in naval battles as well as land.- You can build items such as huge upgradable walls and towers to give your city that 'Empire' feel.- Mulitplayer is still alive and kickingCons:- For a game that came out in 2009, the price tag is high. I'd wait till it's on sale.- AI can be a bit tedious- In multiplayer, players are free to leave mid-game without repecussions.- Lag and frame drop become evident during large muliplayer battles as players can have 200 units each (thats a lot in a 8 player game)Neutral:- Multiplayer games can last a long time ranging from a 20 minute game to a 3hr game.- Hosts tend to choose bias teams during matchmaking.- Single player is a little too easyOverall, an 8.5. I recommend this game purely for the multiplayer aspect. It's just a shame Esemble studios, the developer, was cut loose from Microsoft.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												This game.... THIS GAME!This game is phenomenal! The RTS genre wasn't my favorite type of game (I didn't even want anyrthing to do with it before) but when my friend recommended this game to me I decided to try it out. And, surprise surprise, I love it! I haven't even touched the scenarios yet and I'm having a blast with this game! This is an amazing game to play with friends and maybe alone if you're just wanting to chill and listen to music or a podcast to.The strength of this game is the jump from AoE II's graphics and gameplay. Now, I'm not one to base a game on it's looks because I love AoE II and Rise of Nations as well, but the graphical change give this game a refreshing look to it when you play. But gameplay from AoE II hasn't change a whole lot but has changed a little. The only difference is that A.) You can't build mines next to a silver or gold ore vein, and B.) You can't build a wood mill next to a forest that you're gathering wood from. Now I like that it is a faster and cheeper process to gather wood and gold fast but wood can be scarce at times and the fact that you cannot upgrade your wood gathering speed until the V age kinda bothered me at first, but then I messed around with my 'deck' in the game and by god:THE DECK FEATURE IS AMAZING!The Deck is practically bonus cards that you can use to help benefit you in certain points of the game and can be used either once or infinently and are spread across different era's in the game, for example; The faster wood gathering perk card can be used once and can (possibly) be obtained in the I era, but the faster gold gathering perk may possibly be obtainable in the II era. But for the closing of the AoE III review I have to say this: this game is by far my favorite RTS on the market right now! I was skeptical about it at first, but I'm glad I bought it! I recommend to everybody! This game from me gets a 9/10! Enjoy! :D

content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
												AoE 3, the nostalgia.Third in the AoE series. This game offers a different gameplay style as compared to I and II. The possibility to have home shipments (which in part is predicated on the colonial era settlement) which could to a large extent alter the dynamics of a standard game, can make games very interesting.The usual strategies and min-maxing continues, as are build orders, resource management, positioning and all the other micro and macro management skills are still present.Players new to the game, coming from AoE 1 and/or 2 should be warned that it has a generally different graphical style and generally fosters a more dynamic and fastpaced playstyle.

												Simply the best RTS right now. What I like about it:- eco and micro managing the fights are both important- there are loads of viable strategies- there is more than 1 resource (!!!) wich makes managing economy more demanding- the historical setup with the unit types artillery, cavallery, infantery makes it easier to understand strength and weaknesses of each unit. content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
Age of Empires 3 Complete Collection ReviewAge of Empires 3 Complete Collection is a nice bundle for RTS fans that offers many hours of gameplay. I have been a fan of this series from its beginning. In fact, Age of Empires (the original) was my first PC gaming experience ever and a big reason why I switched from console to PC. If you enjoy this game then I recommend picking up Age of Empires 2 HD and Age of Empres Gold as well. Now, let's get on with the review.Age of Empires 3 is a lot different than its predecessors. Aside from improvements on graphics, it introduces several new features to the series. Home cities are a huge addition to the game. Players get to tinker around and spend upgrade points on their Home Cities to change the appearance of the buildings and environment, but more importantly, during each mission map you are able to receive a variety of shipments (resources, settlers, army troops) from them that help you achieve your goals. These shipments are selected from another new feature, a deck of cards. Players can build custom decks of cards that are somewhat unique to the civilization they are playing as they gain experience from missions played. The shipments you receive from your Home City are based on the deck the player chooses to use prior to beginning each new map.Another new feature is the addition of hero-type units based on the chosen civilization that regenerate health and can perform special abilities. A few new buildings have been added to enhance gameplay in a variety of ways: the fort, the factory, the capitol, and the plantation.  Maps now contain a few new features as well. Players will find treasure locations scattered across each map that can give a variety of rewards. Also, maps now contain "trading routes" that enable players to gain additional experience (used for receiving shipments from Home Cities) or resources once building a trading post along the route in designated areas. The new features added into Age of Empires 3 are integrated extremely well. They enhance overall gameplay and are not just thrown in hastily just to add something different. The bundle contains the base game, the Asian Dynasties expansion, and The War Chiefs expansion. Each of these contain lengthy campaigns to keep players entertained for hours. There is also a new multiplayer feature that players have been wanting for a long time (they even added multiplayer to AoE2). Overall, this game is really great. It plays smoothly on most all systems and is virtually bug-free as it should be since its been on the market for a long time.As with any game, there are some setbacks though. Firstly, it is way too expensive for a game this old. There is a lot of game content included in the bundle but its still not worth paying full price in the Steam store. It doesn't go on sale often but I recommend waiting till it does or else find a 66% off coupon for it. Secondly, players who have previously played other AoE games will find that the maps are much smaller and cramped up compared to the oher franchise releases. To compensate for this, the developers decided to include hefty population costs for various troops. This means that the days of having a huge army to overwhelm your opponent is a thing of the past. The city-building aspect has also been dummied down to the basics which will take some of the enjoyment out of the game for a few. Resources collected by settlers now go straight into the stockpile instead of needing to be deposited at resource collecting points, which takes some of the realism away from the game. Research is still included in the game but is not as intriguing as in the original games. Most notably, there isn't much diversity in the civilizations offered. The troops and research options seem to be the same regardless of which civilization is chosen. The map editor tool feature used to create custom maps and campaigns is no longer included so don't expect a lot of new player-made content to add even more life to the game. And lastly, only two types of smirmishes are available compared to the four types in the previous versions.The Good:========+  3D graphics with rich detail+  Smooth gameplay and controls+  Offered in a bundle+  Quality DLC content+  Great storyline and 3 full campigns+  Numerous new features to enhance gameplay+  High replay value+  Numerous patches to fix bugs from initial release+  Multiplayer online play availableThe Bad:======-  Extremely over-priced for a dated game-  Small player maps-  Limited Skirmish Options-  Simple tech tree-  Civilizations lack true diversity-  Its not Age of Empires 2Final Thoughts:===========Overall, Age of Empires 3 is a fun game that will keep players busy for numerous hours and I recommend it to all RTS game lovers as long as you can pick it up on sale. However, don't load it up and expect it to be anything close to  the other Ensemble Studios titles. In general, the game feels generic and simplistic compared to other games such as Age of Empires 2 or Age of Mythology. Instead, it offers a different style of play due to the numerous new features added and for that reason its worth playing.If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator Group

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
For more reviews and gameplay videos by Morgoth, check out my  Steam profile, the  Youtube channel, and the Twitch channel[twitch.tv]!!Ah, yet another entry into the already incredible Age of Empires franchise.  There are few RTS franchises that can boast about having as much success as AoE has had, and there is good reason behind that.  After putting in nearly 100 hours into the game I can easily say, this one does not disappoint for the most part.  It's no AoE II, but it's close.  That puts this game head and shoulders above most other strategy games.  Ensemble Studios really did an incredible job on their final entry into this series, and they will be greatly missed.Gameplay : The gameplay of this entry in the AoE series is very similar to the previous two.  Build a base/town, build an economy, raise an army, destroy your enemies.  While it might be a simple straightforward process, it's a hell of a lot of fun.  The combat is visceral, the interface is simplistic enough for even brand new strategy game players to get a grasp on it in just a few short minutes, and the payoff is worth it, for the most part.  The only part that seems to have gotten worse in this entry, is the unit path-finding.  I don't know why or how this particular area got worse, but it definitely did.  Units will seemingly go completely out of there way to get to where you want them to go.  And villagers will CONSTANTLY lose track of what they are supposed to be doing.  The Idle Villager button was nice in AoE II, but it wasn't a necessity.  But in AoE III, you will be clicking it every minute.There are several modes of gameplay in this version including but not limited to: Campaign, Single-player Random Maps, Multiplayer Standard, etc.  But all of them hold the same general process of base building and conquering your enemies.  The campaigns are lengthy, but slightly repetitive and the characters are not really that engaging, even in the expansions.  The real gem is the multiplayer.  There are several different civilizations to choose from, each one with incredibly unique units that have completely different capabilities.  So while the units are different, this forces different strategies depending on the civilization you have chosen. This creates a unique experience and feel to each civilization and keeps the gameplay fresh while extending it's longevity.Of course when it comes to multiplayer strategy games, balancing is key.  ESO did a pretty good job of balancing units and civs to begin with, but there were a few missteps in the original that were fixed in the expansions.  So of course the final expansion, The Asian Dynasties, is the definitive AoE III multiplayer experience.  (I don't think you can even play the Warchiefs multiplayer anymore)  I do not wish to go much further in depth with gameplay simply because this is a strategy game and can literally be talked and discussed about forever.  So I'll just finish with this:  The gameplay is really incredible and enjoyable, while also being long-lasting.Graphics : This game was released in 2005.  2005.  I'll say that one more time.  This game was released in 2005.  And it STILL looks better than a ton of games being released these days.  The new physics engine that was put into place for AoE III is incredible and might be the best looking one in strategy games.  Buildings fall apart completely differently depending on what they are being attacked by and how.  Fire two cannons at two different houses, and they will be blown apart in completely different ways, even from the same angles.  This game was WAY ahead of it's time in terms of graphics.  You will often find yourself just sitting and staring in wonderment at the action that is taking place on the screen (when really you should probably be taking care of other things in the game).Sound : The audio is perfectly matched for this game.  All the way from the muskets firing, to armies being demolished by elephants, and to cannons thundering over everything else.  And you will hear those cannons from very far away.  Just this small addition, brings in a massive level of tension to the game (especially when playing with Fog of War on).  You can hear the artillery slowly encroaching on your base, and depending on your level of readiness, you are either swarming around trying to prepare or silently waiting for the first shot to be fired in a battle that will determine the fate of your town.As for the music, it's OK.  I'm a big fan of the soundtracks in the AoE series as they have always meshed ever so perfectly with the gameplay and visuals.  This entry probably has the weakest soundtrack of all three games.  But it's not terrible.  Just OK.Lasting Appeal : This game has tremendous lasting appeal.  And ESO specifically built it that way.  By implementing the new Home City system into this entry, your City can earn experience and level up after almost every match, which unlocks new cards that you can put into your City's deck that provide bonuses that can be called upon during the match.  Anything from a passive bonus to resource gathering rates, to massive extra reinforcement troops.  The servers are still packed with players ready to fight and try to demolish you so don't be afraid of dwindling player base.Final Verdict : This game is definitely an 8/10.  Superb gameplay, fantastic graphics, awesome audio, and great lasting appeal.  Is it worth $40?  Probably not.  That's a lot of asking money for a game that came out in 2005.  I think $30 is much more reasonable.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												I had forgotten just how good this game was. Like many people i'd bought it years ago, only to find my playing days cut short thanks to it being incompatible with Windows Vista onwards. Not any more! I can confirm the Steam version works perfectly on my Windows 8.1 Pro 64-bit system.Fans of the first two games will immediately be able to dive straight in, although there have been some major changes in the third installment compared to the first two. Firstly there's not so much emphasis on micro management now. Instead you get to concentrate on the exploration and battle elements, which makes this game the most enjoyable of the three. Secondly there is the new home city section which allows you to ship units and supplies to the new world during the game. Between games you can customise your home city to change which units and supplies can be sent out to you, along with the appearance of the city itself.Visually this game absolutely trounces the two previous games, and indeed almost any other game in the genre, it is graphically amazing. Sound-wise it's not much different to the first two, with the sound being good but not excellent, and not too intrusive. The campaign isn't too difficult, so the greater challenge will come from skirmish games (rather like Age of Mythology... indeed all previous comparisons to the first two Age of Empires games also apply to Age of Mythology).If you did not have this game before, you really owe it to yourself to buy it now that the compatibility problems have been sorted out and it works fine on Windows 8, 7 and presumably Vista as well. If, like me, you already had this game but could not play it because of those compatibility problems, well i can now confirm that those problems have been solved! This game deserves to be in everyone's collection.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												Age of Empires 3 is an RTS classic, the (unfortunately) last game in the Age of Empires' series installment, was brilliant for it's time, and definitely still can count itself among the best classic RTS' out there, even according to the standards of today for that genre in particular, as well as the Strategy genre as a whole.Aside from this, the game also has an interesting shipment system, which is quite unique, and spices up the game, that is not even mentioning all of the different units, from the different civilizations and their playstyles.The graphics are beginning to show their age, but nevertheless are still quite good, and decent to look at.The AI, though a bit rudimentary, at hard difficulty can easily prove to be quite a challenge, especially if you are fighting the French with the Napoleon personality (viva la Baguette?).The game is not supported anymore, due to it's age, however, you can easily through third party programs like GameRanger find and play multiplayer games online.Oh, and remember to launch the game through Asian Dynasties, as you would otherwise not be able to access the content of all of the DLCs and their content at the same time. Enjoy. : )

content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												Honestly, I really resented this game for years. But I finally broke down and bought it and it is worth every penny. It took some time to get used to the whole cards thing, but once you get past that, its all good.2017 Edit: I would still recommend this game today, but if it was a "one or the other" situation, I'd recommend taking a look at AOE 2: HD. To elaborate a little on my original review, when this game came out, I was a die hard AOE 2 fan still, and a lot of the mechanics in this game (the cards especially) I saw as a gimmick. I figured they had just run out of ideas or something. Thankfully, I was wrong, I haven't played enough of this to say more but its definitely a good buy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 29, 2013
												AoE é um jogo especial para mim. Embora não tenha jogado o primeiro, AoE 2 foi a minha primeira experiência realmente intensa nos pcs: o primeiro game que me dediquei de fato na nossa querida plataforma. Foi uma grande satisfação quando vi AoE 3 disponível no Steam. Assim como o 2, o 3 também joguei bastante. Contudo, à época, joguei as versões piratas. O legal era que, mesmo sendo pirata, conseguíamos jogar on line. Comprei AoE 3 aqui no Steam em retribuição aos momentos de diversão que me proporcionou no passado (e também por saudosismo). O jogo é um ótimo rts, que permite várias práticas estratégicas. As civilizações são realmente muito distintas umas das outras, cada qual com sua árvore evolutiva própria, o que permite aproveitar o game a partir de várias possibilidades de combates diferentes.  Interessante é que ainda hoje ele possui gráficos muito bons. Ademais, é possível achar na net sites com mapas, campanhas, civilizações e outros mods que acrescentam bastante conteúdo free. Enfim, aconselho a todos que gostem de construir cidades, evolui-las, formar exércitos e ir para o fronte de batalha colocar em prática suas estratégias.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												O Age of Empires 3 é um jogo para Windows que faz parte da famosa série Age of Empires. O game se tornou a principal referência quando o assunto é jogos de raciocínio e estratégia. Seu objetivo é administrar as construções da cidade, as tecnologias que estão surgindo e a expansão da sociedade, de forma a fazer com que ela cresça da maneira mais organizada possível. O título faz você viajar pelos séculos e é diversão garantida.Ao iniciar a partida, você volta no tempo e vive como pessoas de outra época. Existem oito civilizações, entre elas: Britânicos, Espanhóis, Portugueses e Franceses. Neste contexto, é possível encontrar minérios, madeira e ouro. Além de comercializar produtos e conseguir comida de qualquer maneira.Nesta versão, mudar o status e evoluir acontece de um jeito diferente das outras versões. A experiência é mais importante e dá mais pontos do que conseguir novas tecnologias. Por isso, não é necessário somente avançar no tempo para adquirir novas ferramentas.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												This is such an amazing game! I have played this game and AOE II since i was around 7 years old and I have to admit the game is still very fresh and enjoyable. Though it is a great game I feel there is a necessary requirement to enjoying this game. Siblings, family or friends! I have been playing this game with my brothers for many years and it is so much fun backstabbing each other, working together and interacting with each other in a video game. I think of it like a board game, it is most enjoyable to play it with people you know instead of robots or random people because it is a way to bond. There are some solo options but the AI are very predictable, the only other option is ES Online which is hard to use since the game is so dated and few people around the world play making for a lot of lag. I give this game 9.75/10 because of the way this game holds a special place in my heart and in the hearts of my brothers.
