number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												I had forgotten just how good this game was. Like many people i'd bought it years ago, only to find my playing days cut short thanks to it being incompatible with Windows Vista onwards. Not any more! I can confirm the Steam version works perfectly on my Windows 8.1 Pro 64-bit system.Fans of the first two games will immediately be able to dive straight in, although there have been some major changes in the third installment compared to the first two. Firstly there's not so much emphasis on micro management now. Instead you get to concentrate on the exploration and battle elements, which makes this game the most enjoyable of the three. Secondly there is the new home city section which allows you to ship units and supplies to the new world during the game. Between games you can customise your home city to change which units and supplies can be sent out to you, along with the appearance of the city itself.Visually this game absolutely trounces the two previous games, and indeed almost any other game in the genre, it is graphically amazing. Sound-wise it's not much different to the first two, with the sound being good but not excellent, and not too intrusive. The campaign isn't too difficult, so the greater challenge will come from skirmish games (rather like Age of Mythology... indeed all previous comparisons to the first two Age of Empires games also apply to Age of Mythology).If you did not have this game before, you really owe it to yourself to buy it now that the compatibility problems have been sorted out and it works fine on Windows 8, 7 and presumably Vista as well. If, like me, you already had this game but could not play it because of those compatibility problems, well i can now confirm that those problems have been solved! This game deserves to be in everyone's collection.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2016
												Age of Empires III: complete Collection is a small compilation consisting of Age of Empires III and the two expansion packs. I already recommend buying this over the retail version since there was an issue with it. If one was to purchase Age of Empires III then War Chiefs and Asian Dynasties retail, it would only allow the use of Asian Dynasties OR War Chiefs. So, one pro is that both expansions can be played at the same time.GameplayAge of Empires III is an RTS that is set in colonial times. What is most appealing about the game is the beautiful graphics for the time and the amount of replayability. The effort that was placed in each nation was specific and displayed the obvious strengths and weaknesses of each nation after some experience. For example, one nation might be unable to build a tower type build, but have a unit or another building that allows better protection against enemies. This also limits the player somewhat since not all nations can just wall up and defend well like in Age of Empires or Age of Empires II. StoryNot much to say on this subject as the story is loosily based on true events and is sub-par at best. To say the least, you would probably play through it once and never touch it again.VisualsThe audio is superb and feels right. The gun shots of the muskets don't sound like bb guns or anything, the ambient music is relaxing, and combat has its own fast paced music as well. Graphic wise, the game is very beautiful and seems to bring out the environments of the real world. Overall, I would recommend this game to long time fans of the series or fans of RTS games.

												It's AoE 3.Granted, tis' not the one that is the most popular in the series (compared to 2, AoM, or even the first one), but there's a lot of replay value when they introduced the card system. You can tweak it to your liking, whether that works or not. They also integrated one of the game modes that I used to play (xx minutes no rush) into the actual game as a game mode, which is fantastic if you like to build up economies and then clash with big arimes on the field. You can also have large navy fights that I haven't seen in a RTS except for the Empire Earth series. Very fun and replayable.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												One of my favorite strategy games of all time.  It's almost a decade old, yet I still find time to play it.Campaign:  8/10  The base game's campaign is broken up into three stories loosely connected via the characters.  The level designs are creative and the gameplay is always engaging.  For first time players, the campaigns are a good place to learn the intricacies of the game.Skirmishes:  9/10  The base game has 8 or 9 "Home Cities" to choose from, each with unique units, buildings, etc.  Each Home City gains experience independently, so there is no shortage of game to be played.  The map selection is very diverse, especially if you indulge in the expansion packs.  The AI can be a little idiotic at easier difficulties, but challenging at harder ones.  The only fault I find with the gameplay is the lack of diversity among the units available.  Each Home City has access to a different combination of a dozen or so units, each with a specific purpose in your armies, so if you opponent is building mostly cavalry, you just build anti-cavalry units.  This can become stale after several games.Graphics:  8/10  What can I say?  The game looks great, especially considering its age.  The building models are great and 'evolve' as you age up in-game.  The landscape and scenery are very well detailed, notably the water and trees.  The game even has some physics involved when you attack buildings and the buildings fall apart.  The only fault I find with the graphics are the character models, which dont have idle animations and have identical faces, uniforms, etc.  Overall, I give this game a solid 85/100.  You might get bored of it, butonly after many hours of rewarding gameplay.  By the way, the soundtrack is fantastic.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2016
												Age of Empires III: complete Collection is a small compilation consisting of Age of Empires III and the two expansion packs. I already recommend buying this over the retail version since there was an issue with it. If one was to purchase Age of Empires III then War Chiefs and Asian Dynasties retail, it would only allow the use of Asian Dynasties OR War Chiefs. So, one pro is that both expansions can be played at the same time.GameplayAge of Empires III is an RTS that is set in colonial times. What is most appealing about the game is the beautiful graphics for the time and the amount of replayability. The effort that was placed in each nation was specific and displayed the obvious strengths and weaknesses of each nation after some experience. For example, one nation might be unable to build a tower type build, but have a unit or another building that allows better protection against enemies. This also limits the player somewhat since not all nations can just wall up and defend well like in Age of Empires or Age of Empires II. StoryNot much to say on this subject as the story is loosily based on true events and is sub-par at best. To say the least, you would probably play through it once and never touch it again.VisualsThe audio is superb and feels right. The gun shots of the muskets don't sound like bb guns or anything, the ambient music is relaxing, and combat has its own fast paced music as well. Graphic wise, the game is very beautiful and seems to bring out the environments of the real world. Overall, I would recommend this game to long time fans of the series or fans of RTS games.

content:
Posted: September 19, 2014
PROS:+ fun campaign stories+ nice building & unit variety+ AoE look+ XP system+ fun multiplayer+ two cool expansionsCONS:- simplified building & resource gathering- home base cards- the unit formations are useless- lacks stuff that would make this game iconic like the first twoComment:Do not be fooled by the hours played I have displayed here as I have played many many more. So to this date this is the last AoE games made. It has lots of new stuff and is very inovative from the first two...and yet...a bit boring compared to them. For some reason the developers simplified building stuff and gathering resources then they added home cards and reinforcements. At first it looked cool. But as you play it somehow distracts you, from the game, from the upgrades selectable in the buildings. It lost the AoE charm. By no means is this a bad game! But it falls short even with the great War Chiefs and Asian Dynasties expansion packs. I truly do recommend this as a RTS game because it is good, but it just lacks something to be really great...

content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												This is the game that gave me my love for both strategy and History itself.  Until I got Civilization V, this game was by far my most played strategy game.  You get to fight in the New World or Asia as you build up resorces, construct an army, and conquer your neighbors!  Though I feel the game should add more factions to play like Sweden, Austria, or Denmark to add to to the already great experience (without the need of a mod) and the ability to fight in Europe!  Also, if you're a person who doesn't like to win legitimently, then look of some of the cheats, the're hilarious!  Also, the AI difficulty is very spaced out between easy, moderate, and hard, unlike some games that have easy WAY too easy, medium has a massive jump from easy, and hard is nearly impossible.  Great choice if you're a stategy fan.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2016
Age of Empires III is a great base-building RTS game for older and less powerful rigs.This game will run on almost any machine that will run Windows 10 as long as it has the space requirements met.  It's quick to load and easy to host/join.  It's not online-only.  It has single-player campaigns, one for the base game and one for each expansion, and it has LAN support.  (It has online features, too, though I never mess with that.)The game is real-time strategy or RTS at its core.  It offers a lot of resource-gathering options and many ways to creatively gain a foothold over your competition.  It also has hilarious cheats! If you don't care to cheat your way to victory but need an edge over everyone else on the battlefield, there is the handicap percentage.Why do I play this so often over all my other RTS games?My wife's laptop can't play much else.  That's the biggest reason.  We like playing strategy games cooperatively and AOE3 is one of the best-looking, most fun experiences we've got to work on her laptop.  Someday, I want to build her a gaming desktop out of my old parts so she can play newer, prettier RTS games.  Even then, we'll probably compare all of them to AOE3.

												Some people prefer age of empires 2, but this still has got a lot of advantages and excellent updates, worthy to be considered a sequel. There is a lot less micromanaging of the unenjoyable kind as you can train 5 units at the speed of 1 and villagers don't have to travel back to resource drop off points. It feel more action packed and lacks the dull late game turtling that age of empires 2 would drive to. The AI can be an absolute retard at times but they can come up with excellent tactical decisions. I actually prefer this to AOE 2, and it certainly has made a lot of changes that makes it stand out with its independant identity within the AOE franchise.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												I love Age of Empires 3. I played tons of AoE2 growing up and still do (especially with the AoE2 HD available on Steam). It's such a great game and never gets boring. I really enjoy card system in AoE3. I think it adds an extra level of customization, and you can make separate decks for when you are on different kinds of maps. I also love that I don't have to put buildings near resources in order for the villagers to transport goods. Instead, they can just keep on chipping away and there will be a steady stream of resources being acquired. If you want to see some funny physics, cluster a bunch of ships close together and watch them twitch. Overall: great game is great!

content:
Posted: March 31, 2014
												Okay, here's how it is. If you absolutley adore Age of Empires 2 and want a clone, don't play this. If you like StarCraft 2 or similair games, Play this. Nice story, nice graphics, decent gameplay. The multi-player is not very fun unless it's with friends. There is mild customization. Such as which nation to play in skirmish. The "card system" is a little odd, but effective if you like it.   I have seen all the bad reviews, they all hate that this game isn't AOE2. The game is simple. Spam musketeers and two cannons and you win. But the story is fun. The historical accuracy is off, but this is a video game, not a history lesson. All in all, play it if you want a fun simple RTS with ninjas.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
												8/10If you like the classic RTS style – that is building a base, collecting resources, amassing a giant army, and eventually crushing your opponent with massive amounts of soldiers – this is a great choice. It includes two expansion packs which extend the play time considerably. Graphics are a bit dated but look fine. You get a lot of game for your money and if you find it on sale don’t hesitate to buy. Single player missions are fun and somewhat varied in their objectives; it will take you a long time to finish. The challenge is decent but you probably won’t be failing too many missions.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												This has always been a favored game of mine, and the fact at how it has moved to steam im sure has helped a lot more. Firstly I can say, That it helps me store this game just as much as just discs have, giving me a chance to play whenever I wish. And if you are a real expert or ever have played this game on the multiplayer servers, I can definately tell it has saved The Ensemble Studios Online section.  In the good old days, there were about 2000 acconts and people on average, and now its peak hits over the 1100 mark, (Im sure that the moving to steam has helped the gameplay and popularity of the game and multiplayer mode).  Overall, the gameplay is and has always been great, especially for the time when this game came out.  Great story and campaignlines. 3 campaigns for the Vanilla Version, 2 for the Warchiefs, and 3 for the Asian Dynasties.Great History too! Not only featuring countless Military, Civilian Populations, Plus various amounts of warships, weapon(Cannon/Infantry) types.  Age of empires 3 consists of various playable civilizations. The Vanilla/Nilla version  with just the european powers shows 8 civs. The British, French, Spanish, Germans, Dutch, Portugese, Ottomans, and Russians.  The Warchiefs Expansion Includes more maps, and The Iroqois Civilization, The Sioux and the Aztecs. The Asian Dynasties includes even more maps, and the Japanese, Chinese, and Indian Civilizations, and what can i say.  I love it all!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												One of the best RTS games created.Should you buy this, you will not be dissapointed with your purchase.Best feature for me? The Expansion Packs were actually expansions that changed the game in multiple ways and added on to the complete/full base form of the game. What I mean is, normally DLC nowadays is required to get the full package of what the final product should've been. AoE3's Expansion Packs ARE NOT DLC. The Expansion Packs in AoE3 add on to the game content enough to make it feel like a different game within a game. The Expansion Packs aren't neccessary to fully enjoy Age of Empires III; however, having them improves upon the player experience greater.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8, 2016
												A huge big YES.I have followed and been loyal to the Age of Empires series since it was first released and I still think that I owe my whole career (foreign language teacher and translator) to this game as this is where I was exposed to foreign languages for the first time. Aside from that, Age of Empires just has the perfect blend of city building and combat mixed in with some micromanagement (especially in AOEIII) which has sometimes resulted in having multiplayer games lasting more than 4 hours at a time, 4v4. I will always cherish this game and come back to it, especially AOEIII as it's set in one of my favourite time periods in world history. I would recommend buying both expansions though if you have to choose, get the War Chiefs as it adds a certain 'something' that I don't think Asian Dynasties got quite right. I'm still hoping that one day, just one day, there will be an AOE IV and maybe even V and VI, maybe set in WW1, WW2 and Cold War era?

												In my opinion, this is the best RTS, and perhaps best video game ever made. Despite being over a decade old, it still holds up as a great game which can be played over and over for hundreds, if not thousands of hours. The music and gameplay of this is excellent, and while the graphics may not be top-notch, they are decent for the game and allow it be played without much lag interruption. With 14 playable factions and multiple gamemodes, you'll stay interested and there is always something new to do with the excellent scenario making of this game.I would rate this game 10/10. It is a masterpiece.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												A Timeless classic reborn in HD. The Age Of Empires series stands upon one of the three pillars of RTS royalty with the other two being Comand and Conquor and Dawn of War. AOE is one of those games you can spend hours on just fiddling away, building up a strong empire only to loose it when you win. But thats half the fun because you get to do it again. I often found myself building a strong base only to toy with my enemies before i crused them.In many aspects this game seems more ridgid and strict than the ones before, but on the whole i beleive it to be an improvement. With a single player campaign that i actually enjoyed playing this is my favourite in the series.A strong 8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												This has always been a favored game of mine, and the fact at how it has moved to steam im sure has helped a lot more. Firstly I can say, That it helps me store this game just as much as just discs have, giving me a chance to play whenever I wish. And if you are a real expert or ever have played this game on the multiplayer servers, I can definately tell it has saved The Ensemble Studios Online section.  In the good old days, there were about 2000 acconts and people on average, and now its peak hits over the 1100 mark, (Im sure that the moving to steam has helped the gameplay and popularity of the game and multiplayer mode).  Overall, the gameplay is and has always been great, especially for the time when this game came out.  Great story and campaignlines. 3 campaigns for the Vanilla Version, 2 for the Warchiefs, and 3 for the Asian Dynasties.Great History too! Not only featuring countless Military, Civilian Populations, Plus various amounts of warships, weapon(Cannon/Infantry) types.  Age of empires 3 consists of various playable civilizations. The Vanilla/Nilla version  with just the european powers shows 8 civs. The British, French, Spanish, Germans, Dutch, Portugese, Ottomans, and Russians.  The Warchiefs Expansion Includes more maps, and The Iroqois Civilization, The Sioux and the Aztecs. The Asian Dynasties includes even more maps, and the Japanese, Chinese, and Indian Civilizations, and what can i say.  I love it all!

content:
Posted: April 8, 2016
												A huge big YES.I have followed and been loyal to the Age of Empires series since it was first released and I still think that I owe my whole career (foreign language teacher and translator) to this game as this is where I was exposed to foreign languages for the first time. Aside from that, Age of Empires just has the perfect blend of city building and combat mixed in with some micromanagement (especially in AOEIII) which has sometimes resulted in having multiplayer games lasting more than 4 hours at a time, 4v4. I will always cherish this game and come back to it, especially AOEIII as it's set in one of my favourite time periods in world history. I would recommend buying both expansions though if you have to choose, get the War Chiefs as it adds a certain 'something' that I don't think Asian Dynasties got quite right. I'm still hoping that one day, just one day, there will be an AOE IV and maybe even V and VI, maybe set in WW1, WW2 and Cold War era?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2016
												AoE 3 is a pretty decent historical fiction RTS.  The game takes place mostly around the frontier days, with the exception of the Asian Dynasty pack.  I'll be talking a lot about that expansion because it's vastly different from the rest of the game.  Voice acting is decent, as are the stories, predictable though they are.  The music is catchy but highly repetitive.  85% of the game has no chill.  While it's not really all that challenging on Normal difficulty, most of the missions in the game have some kind of time or mechanical constraint that prevent them from being standard "build then destroy" affairs.  Normally I wouldn't complain about this, but themes are re-used so much that they quickly grow old.  "Oh, I don't start off with a base again."  "Oh, I can't get any villagers again."  "Oh, I don't get any resources so I have to use trading posts again."  So on and so forth.  The UI is kind of bad.  It eats up a third of my screen on 1080p, and hotkeys (of which there are many) aren't discernible via mouseovers of the buttons, so you wind up having to go back into the Options menu repeatedly if you want to use them.  Attack-move seemed not to work properly for me, which was very noticeable but not a dealbreaker.  Asian Dynasties involved very different mechanics.  Minus the UI, the production value, and a couple of buildings/progressions, it was almost different enough to be another RTS.  Some of the alterations were neat, others were bizarre.  If you play the Chinese faction during Skirmish mode, they can't build any common soldiers until they Age Up (upgrade the town hall), only siege units.  I'm sorry, what?  Whose brilliant idea was that?  You see, although there are many factions, there are really only four styles in the game:  European, Japanese, Chinese, and Indian.  It's not merely a difference in units, or buildings, but the fundamental mechanics of how they work.  Because I didn't spend a lot of hours in Skirmish mode, it's impossible for me to say if the game is balanced, but I doubt it.Something that appealed to me were the farming/shipment mechanics.  There's food, wood, coin, and a separate export resource if you're playing Asian Dynasties.  The way it's handled, however, you can build farms or receive shipments that are slow, infinite pools of any of those things.  If you run out of wild animals to hunt, build a farm or raise livestock.  If you run out of gold, plantations or rice paddies are infinite.   Wood is more difficult, but Asian Dynasties allows you to plant groves, or you can receive shipments in any case.  As a result, resource-management in the game is a lot less stressful than pretty much any RTS I've played.  Another thing that stood out is the ability to train stacks of five.  If you have the resources, you can train five troops in one building at once, and when it's finished five will pop out.  The need for multiple barracks is basically absent.  That's about everything that stood out for me.  I wouldn't pay 40 dollars for the game, wait for a decent sale, but it's definitely worth picking up for RTS fans if you don't mind historical backdrop.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2016
												So this review was planned to be targeted towards those people that think it as negative that this game plays seemingly alot differently than the previous two games. However, I don't know where this review will be going as I am typing spontanously.First off, this game does play differently. Alot, actually. From what I have seen, the gameplay from Age of Empires 2, especially online, solely consists of spewing out as many villagers as possible in a short time, hamster all the resources to build yourself up quickly and just make a ♥♥♥♥♥on of units, preferably cannoniers and siege cannons.However, in Age of Empires 3 this is simply not possible, as the population cap is already at 200; considering that unit types [e.g. Musketeers as light infantry, Helbardiers as Heavy Infantry, Light Cavalry, Ranged Cavalry, etc.] it is mandatory to have a balance in your army, as the quantity is limited. In this game it is necessary to think about the numbers of Helbardiers to defend your ranged units against enemy melee soldiers, the numbers of Skirmisher to strike down enemy infantry, the number of cavalry to attack the enemy's ranged units, additionally the number of cannons who are deadly agaist masses, and so on, and so on.Personally, having to think about such things instead of spamming units seems way more fun.Same thing is to be said about the buildings.Unlike Age of Empires 2, in this game most buildings can be build limited times only; you cannot build a wall of towers anymore to defend yourself, you can only build 11. You cannot build a Fort (basically AoE3's version of a Castle) in front of the enemy's town because for one, you cannot build things too close to the enemy's town centre, and for two, most civilizations can only have one or two forts in the entire game which can only be built by special wagons, making the risk of losing a fort far more tragic.These special wagons can only be sent by home shipment cards, along with other things that make your resource gather rate higher, send you a certain number of units, resource crates, and wagons which build towers/forts/town centres for free.This seemed to be a thing that could have confused fans of Age of Empires 2 at first (the only reference I have about this is my cousin who didn't like this specific mechanic, don't bash me), I mysel thought the game to be too complicated, although this turnt out to be entirely false as the home shipment system is far more simple than expected.Most civilizations in Age of Empires 3 differ alot from each other; Chinese can only build "armies" which are essentially packs of 2 different soldier-types; Ottomans produce villagers automatically and for free, however this takes longer and the production process has to be sped up with upgrades; they lack melee infantry and instead of having a musketeer unit, they use a more expensive and stronger Janissary unit. I could go into more detaill into the different civilizations like the Aztecs which only have Infantry, but it is best to discover all these things for oneself or just googling it, as this review would take too long.Ye.I love it.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2014
												Okay, here's how it is. If you absolutley adore Age of Empires 2 and want a clone, don't play this. If you like StarCraft 2 or similair games, Play this. Nice story, nice graphics, decent gameplay. The multi-player is not very fun unless it's with friends. There is mild customization. Such as which nation to play in skirmish. The "card system" is a little odd, but effective if you like it.   I have seen all the bad reviews, they all hate that this game isn't AOE2. The game is simple. Spam musketeers and two cannons and you win. But the story is fun. The historical accuracy is off, but this is a video game, not a history lesson. All in all, play it if you want a fun simple RTS with ninjas.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Great game! The improved graphics and gameplay are definitely a step up from the 2nd game in the AoE series. The ships are a lot more realistic in size, and your army sports some new equipment (namely, guns). The one thing that I don't like about this is the resources. For example, in AoE 2, you had to build a mill, and then build farms in order to gather food. You would also have to constantly resupply your farmland. In AoE 3, however, it's more of a one-time-deal; you build a mill, which comes with farmland included, and that's it. You don't have to resupply the mill with more wood to keep the farm going. You can just let it sit there for forever. Now while some people may like this, I personally, am not a huge fan of it as since it makes the game a bit TOO easy. Overall though, definitely still a good game and a worthy buy.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												As a proud AoE fanboy, I was delighted to learn a steam version had become available. AoE3 is something of a unique RTS game in that it is well balanced vanilla (prior to expansions) because of nearly a decade worth of patching. While the expansions fail to deliver as solid a RTS experience (and bump the faction count from 8 to 14), they aren't inherently bad either.I was pleased to learn also that my ESO log in and password still worked after all this time.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
												I spent years playing Age of Empires 2 + Age of Kings expansion. Since I'm not much of a RTS fan, I never liked other strategy games much, but AoE 1&2 were a pleasure for me. When AoE3 first came out, I tried it, but didn't like it. It was annoying to young me, because I was used to AoE2-like gameplay, and the sudden change was something I hated in AoE3.Years have passed, and a friend talked me into buying AoE3. We started playing it together, and it changed my opinion completely. While he is a huuuuuge fan, I wouldn't call myself a fan, but I like the game very much. It's smooth, and has some interesting advantages compared to older AoE titles.Although I'm still not a good RTS player, and I still don't really like playing RTS games, AoE3 captured my time. When played with a friend, this game is a great co-op opportunity. A variety of races, all with their unique units and strategies, makes this game what it is: A classic.Although I loved the game, I must say that Age of Empires 3: Complete Collection is not worth buying at 37€. It's too expensive, and is old enough to fall below the 15€ mark. However, if you're like me, and like sales - buy the game when its price gets low enough for your expectations.My score: 7.3/10

content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												Since I was introduced to Age Of Empires II back in 1999, I was instantly in love with the series. For years I have played AoE2 and all of the sudden Age Of Empires III came out. The sheer awesomeness, value and inginuety that went into making this game can be felt in almost every detail. Be it the campaigns, the skirmish modes, the homecity mechanics or the general polish - everything is just cool. Even today, almost 10 years aftet its initial release back in fall 2005. The game looks great, plays great and even though many fans of AoE say that it might be step back, I can totally recommend this gem from a long lost age when real time strategy was at its pinnacle. The price might be a bit high, but it is much better than buying the games seperately for 50€ each. I did that. And then I bought this back on steam again. Fans of the genre can really grab it now or wait for a rare sale of this game.So all in all, this game is great and ..... WOLOLO!

content:
Posted: April 9, 2016
												I had this game (sans expansions) as a series of burned discs I would occasionally borrow from a friend. I say friend, what I really mean is "guy I sat next to in visual basic." Regardless of who he was, I got to play AoE3 from start to finish back in highschoolWhen it comes to the third game in the series, most people completely ignored the good about AoE3. I recall all my friends going on long, nonsensical tirades against AoE3. Mostly due to two things. The first, and most often bi*ched about, was the new twist on gameplay. AoE3 gameplay is basically the same as the first two games except for one major difference; the home city. The home city is a mechanic in AoE3 that allows you to recieve relief supplies from your civs capital. Everything from general supplies (wood, meat, gold) to extra soldiers (some of which can only be obtained from the home city.) Why this mechanic should stir everyones bile, I will never understand. The second was the story. AoE2 had several campaigns in which you controlled historical figures and reenacted historical events. AoE3 has a single campaign (unless you have the expansions) centered around a shady, almost illuminati type group trying to seize control of the fountain of youth. Pure fantasy, but well written. My friends though, sh*t on it. Back then, AoE players were a bit like todays SMASH players. Speaking of multiplayer...Microsoft has decided you must use there servers to play online. As far as I can tell, you cannot play LAN and you can't host your own internet server. The real problem is that microsofts servers dont seem to work, as they are down almost all the time. Check the community hub for details. Fortunately (for me) this whole multiplayer clusterf*ck doesn't effect me. I mostly play skirmish.Another issue is the price, what is with some companies (bethesda and microsoft) that they feel their games don't depriciate? Age of Empires 3 was released in October of 2005, and as of the writing of this review, it costs 40$. 40 f*ckin bucks for a game released ten years ago, holy sh*t, the price has dropped a grand total of 10$. One dollar a year. Buy this game on sale, or from a bundle. I do reccomend this game, but if you are paying 40$ for it, you are being ripped off.

												Since I was introduced to Age Of Empires II back in 1999, I was instantly in love with the series. For years I have played AoE2 and all of the sudden Age Of Empires III came out. The sheer awesomeness, value and inginuety that went into making this game can be felt in almost every detail. Be it the campaigns, the skirmish modes, the homecity mechanics or the general polish - everything is just cool. Even today, almost 10 years aftet its initial release back in fall 2005. The game looks great, plays great and even though many fans of AoE say that it might be step back, I can totally recommend this gem from a long lost age when real time strategy was at its pinnacle. The price might be a bit high, but it is much better than buying the games seperately for 50€ each. I did that. And then I bought this back on steam again. Fans of the genre can really grab it now or wait for a rare sale of this game.So all in all, this game is great and ..... WOLOLO!

content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
												This is honestly my favorite game ever. I have logged more than 2k games on my old account starting about 2008 up till last year when the complete addition came up on the humble bundle and I started playing with a  new account. I don't play as much due the time needed ( I like long economic battles) and the lack of players at times. This game got me into gaming consistantly and PC gaming in general. If you like RTS games this is perfect for you. If you like FPS this is actually pretty fast paced. Easy game to learn, hard to master, still can't get the Germans and Russians to work.10/10, One of the greatest game ever produced. Wish the developers were still around.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 17, 2013
												I have been playing Age of Empires series since I was very young. When I saw that this collection of third game has appeared on Steam, I didnt hesitate with getting it.Age of Empires III is a real time strategy game set into colonizing the New World to industrial revolution. Game is divided into Campaign, Skirmish mode and Multiplayer. Campaign is divided into 3 parts for each expansion and vanilla game.In single player skirmish you fight against AI in randomly created maps. After game you gain experience for your home town and get better units and upgrades. It has kind of appealing RPG like system to keep you playing. Multiplayer is practically same except that you cannot use your home cities and profiles from skirmish to keep the game balanced. Even that I must warn you. Multiplayer is filled with veterans and very experienced players. I recommend to host game with your friends to enjoy the best experience.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												This is a GREAT game. a little out dated graphically, and in some ways can become somewhat repetitive. but the gameplay itself delivers a well balanced tactical strategy, that changes with every new round. Factors such as locations of resources, natural land obstacles, the strengths and weaknesses of which team you play as, which team you are playing against, and timing of every move all come in to play. If you are looking for a graphically superior game, this is not for you, but if you are looking for a well balanced game that tests your wit on decision making and productivity, this is for you!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												I know many who love the original Age of Empires games (especially #2) hate this game or mock it for not being like the others. I grew up on Age of Empires 2 and it remains to be one of my favourite games of all time. Unlike the others I love this game as much, maybe even more, for fixing the small issues in the other games and generally making a more polished product.  The campaigns are more exciting and the combat more visceral. The expansions add many new civilizations with a whole new set of playstyles the likes of which the franchise hasn't seen before! The point of this short review is to convince people that the naysayers are wrong and that this product is the perfect swan song for Ensemble Studios.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												An amazing sequel! Better graphics, better game play better everything! Age of Empires 3, has a very fun levelling system which each level you gain special cards that will give you perks for your colony. These can be customised into the players own 'deck' which then can be used while in game on multiplayer or skirmish, and it’s amazing. This immersive system really brings the thrill of a well planned strategic battle, keeping you hooked for hours. Although the multiplayer setting is extremely harsh on new players, you may have to spend half your time trying to find a lobby that will allow you to join; once you've reached a reasonable level, the game is at its peak. 10/10

												when i was 8, i started to play this game but later when i got little bit older, i was thinking that the (Age Of Empires 4) will come out, so i did wait and wait. year after year. but one day i was thinking that maybe the game is out, so did ask father but he didn't know anything, so i did for myself, i Searched (Age Of Empires 3) and then i finded the Developers. when i did finded the name, i Searched for them, and i finded an link, i clicked on the link. and when i started to read it. i was schocked.wikipedia:Ensemble Studios was a video game developer initially established in 1995 as an independent company by Tony Goodman, Rick Goodman and John Boog-Scott, but was acquired by Microsoft in 2001 and operated as an internal studio until 2009, when it was officially disbanded.[1] Ensemble developed many real-time strategy games, including the Age of Empires game series, Age of Mythology, and Halo Wars. In addition to game development, Ensemble Studios also made the Genie Game Engine used in Age of Empires, Age of Empires II: The Age of Kings, and Star Wars: Galactic Battlegrounds. The studio sold 20 million games and was worth an estimated $500 million.[2]ReleaseDate	Title	Genre1997	Age of Empires	real-time strategy1998	Age of Empires: The Rise of Rome	expansion pack1999	Age of Empires II: The Age of Kings	real-time strategy2000	Age of Empires II: The Conquerors	expansion pack2001	Star Wars: Galactic Battlegrounds	real-time strategy2002	Star Wars: Galactic Battlegrounds: Clone Campaigns	expansion pack2002	Age of Mythology	real-time strategy2003	Age of Mythology: The Titans	expansion pack2005	Age of Empires III	real-time strategy2006	Age of Empires III: The WarChiefs	expansion pack2007	Age of Empires III: The Asian Dynasties[3]	expansion pack2009	Halo Wars	real-time strategyCancelled	:Titan (Halo MMO)[4][5]	massively multiplayer online gameSorcerer[6]	fantasy-adventure RPGNova[6]	Wrench[6][7]	platform gameBam[6]	Agent[6]	so i'm trying to say that (Age Of Empires 4) will not come out because the Developers closed the Platform. :(Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ensemble_Studios

												Shame this franchise died but great last game to go out on.
